LN(1) General Commands Manual LN(1)

NAME

ln — create hard and symbolic links

SYNOPSIS

ln [-finsv] target link_name

ln [-finsv] target

ln [-finsv] target ... directory

ln [-finsv] -t directory target ...

DESCRIPTION

The ln utility creates a link named link_name which references target. By default, ln creates hard links.

In the second form, ln creates a link to target in the current directory.

In the third and fourth forms, ln creates links to each target in the specified directory.

The options are as follows:

-f
Remove existing destination files.
-i
Prompt before removing existing destination files.
-n
Do not follow symbolic links when determining if the destination is a directory.
-r
With -s, create symbolic links relative to the link's location.
-s
Create symbolic links instead of hard links. Symbolic links can reference files that do not exist.
-t directory
Create links in the specified directory.
-v
Print the name of each file as it is linked.

Hard links cannot span file systems and cannot reference directories. Symbolic links can reference any file or directory and are resolved at the time of access.

EXAMPLES

Create a hard link:

$ ln file.txt hardlink.txt

Create a symbolic link:

$ ln -s /usr/bin/vim vi

Create multiple links in a directory:

$ ln -s file1.txt file2.txt links/

Create a relative symbolic link:

$ ln -sr /home/user/file.txt /home/user/docs/link
$ ls -l /home/user/docs/link
lrwxrwxrwx 1 user user 11 Jul 26 08:45 link -> ../file.txt

EXIT STATUS

The ln utility exits 0 on success, and >0 if an error occurs.

DIAGNOSTICS

cross-device link
Hard links cannot span file systems. Use symbolic links instead.
file exists
The destination file already exists. Use -f to overwrite.
is a directory
Hard links cannot reference directories.

SEE ALSO

link(2), symlink(2), rm(1), readlink(1)

STANDARDS

The ln utility is compliant with the IEEE Std 1003.1-2008 (“POSIX.1”) specification.

August 2, 2025 macOS 15.6
